1125790686157135873.text: When backcountry camping in Glacier, keep in mind you must secure your food and trash properly. This will prevent bears, squirrels, and other critters from tearing open your bags and eating “people” food that is harmful for them. For more info, visit: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/backcountry.htm …pic.twitter.com/5jsSDQSVEC

#glaciernps #geologyrockspic.twitter.com/QFgH7kahDV

1123677410912817154.text: This year we've had some staffing changes and delays in hiring, so we are working very hard to open the area. 1123677144595468288.text: The road to Two Medicine typically opens when road conditions allow, and staffing levels and infrastructure are up and running to provide basic services in the area. Last year the road opened on May 18, and this year, the park expects that the road will open approx mid-May.

Wondering what happened here?
Alarming as it appears, it is neither a crime scene nor the result of a predator-prey interaction. It is, in fact, a puddle of melted Watermelon Snow.
Watermelon snow is caused by an algae that give it a red pigment.
#dontdrinkthewaterpic.twitter.com/UTekKNFcB2

The fossil resources that are preserved in Glacier give a glimpse into the beginning of life on our planet. Here we find massive beds of stromatolites, which are rock-hard buildups of bacterial mats.

1115309627955003392.text: Glaciers are masses of snow and ice that are so big they move under the influence of gravity. Ever wonder what the biggest danger to visitors in the park is? (It’s not !) It’s water. Water is the biggest cause of fatalities in the park, and these deaths are often associated with falling.

1057731280039636992.text: Bat Week is at its end, but the importance of bats to our ecosystem goes far beyond Bat Week. Yet, bats are facing a crisis—white-nose syndrome. Learn what researchers are doing to prepare for the disease in this new video.https://youtu.be/SwWQ1Sv4SvQ

1055906964117602305.text: This fuzzy critter is a California myotis. It is a small bat with pale, dull fur and narrow, pointed ears. The California myotis eats a variety of insects including moths and flies. It was recently added to Glacier's species list after being detected by bat researchers. #Batheropic.twitter.com/grSuzhVTCf

1055222248213118977.text: It’s time to get batty! Bat Week starts today! In its fifth year, Bat Week is a celebration of bats and their importance to our ecosystem. 1055143378642325504.text: There are no obvious signs of decline in Glacier's moose populations but moose have been declining across much of North America in recent years. One hypothesis is that increasingly milder winters in recent decades have been favorable for ticks who love to prey on moose.

1030538581461282816.text:
In fact, 80 to 90% of the mass of wildfire smoke comes from particulates smaller than 2.5 micrometers. These fine particulates (as well as the presence of carbon monoxide) are what make exposure to smoke unhealthy for humans. 
Regional air quality: http://svc.mt.gov/deq/todaysair/

1030538580345610240.text: The smoke we see around the park today is made of many different solid and liquid particulates, but mostly carbon dioxide and water vapor. Most of the particulates in wildfire smoke are too small to be seen, less than 7 micrometers. #ScienceFriday #HoweRidgeFire

1030538579406086144.text: Sometimes smoke can settle in for multiple days, and sometimes it can be gone in a matter of hours. Additionally, the park is over one million acres, so smoke in one area may not necessarily mean smoke in another (though sometimes it is truly regional).https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/conditions.htm …

1030538577174654976.text: You've likely been seeing a lot of news coverage lately about smoke. Air quality questions are some of our top inquiries right now at the park. One of your best sources for information is the park's webcams. https://www.nps.gov/glac/learn/photosmultimedia/webcams.htm …pic.twitter.com/UZadHkrO7W

1030127242779668481.text: Reminder: Glacier and most of western Montana are in Stage II Fire Restrictions. No campfires will be permitted in Glacier. Smoking is prohibited except within an enclosed building, vehicle, developed recreation area, or barren area. Propane stoves are permitted.

1029537953935065088.text: The NPS believes that 3 outbuildings of the NPS-owned Wheeler residence were lost. The main Wheeler cabin did survive, after valiant firefighting efforts that saved it after it caught fire. Lake McDonald Ranger Station was also saved, despite a fire on its roof.

1029537952769036288.text: Approximately 7 private summer residences and additional outbuildings were lost at Kelly’s Camp at the end of North Lake McDonald Road. One Kelly’s Camp home did survive the fire, as did multiple other homes and structures.

1029537951774994432.text: Structural protection task force from Flathead County saved several buildings Sunday evening but some structures were lost. The National Park Service has not completed a full inventory of all infrastructure & additional losses may be documented later.

1029537948620865536.text: The fire is still very active and estimated at 2,578 acres. Conditions in the fire area remain hot and dry. You can stay updated by checking out the #HoweRidgeFire page on @inciweb here: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/6135/Howe …pic.twitter.com/RU6Jll2x86

1029537945139605504.text: Specific information about trail and road closures and evacuation areas can be found on Glacier's website: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/conditions.htm …pic.twitter.com/uQEtEPzklm

1029537944141320192.text: Here's a thread of updates on the Howe Ridge Fire: The lightning-caused fire made a significant run on Sunday night, despite active air and ground firefighting efforts. The fire prompted multiple evacuations and closures. Learn more on our press page:https://www.nps.gov/glac/learn/news/newsreleases.htm …

1028000811496992769.text:
To learn more about one endangered stonefly species in Glacier, visit:
https://www.fws.gov/mountain-prairie/es/westernglacierstonefly.php …

1028000804702248961.text: These insects are sensitive to changes in water quality, such as increases in temperature and the presence of pollutants. Therefore, scientists monitor the abundance of stoneflies and other insects to measure how climate change and other stressors are impacting our ecosystems.pic.twitter.com/7VyuHYQfZ4

1028000797701939200.text: Stoneflies spend most of their lives in a larval stage, and can be found crawling along the bottom of flowing bodies of water. Some species are predatory, while others prefer eating plants and organic debris.pic.twitter.com/yGp36keBpm

1028000790324170759.text: It's a bear! It's a moose! It's a...stonefly larvae? While visitors often enjoy spotting some of Glacier's larger, more charismatic animals, other important members of our ecosystems lie hidden just beneath the surface of our rivers and streams.pic.twitter.com/fJtNZx1Nr5

If your fire gets out of control, note your location and call 911 for assistance. If there is no cell service, contact the nearest park ranger or campground host to report the fire.

 Here’s some great information on campfires in National Parks:https://www.nps.gov/articles/campfires.htm …

1014313852912074752.text: Never leave a campfire unattended. Always keep water nearby when you have a campfire. You might have a sudden need to put it out or the weather might change dramatically.

How do you make your campfires?!

The smell of woodsmoke and the pop and hiss of burning wood in a campfire brightens any night out in Glacier!

1013569150445281281.text: If you're planning on visiting Logan Pass, check the weather before making the trip. Bring layers, snacks, and water, and be prepared for a variety of conditions: sun, clouds, rain, snow, and wind.

1013569149409214464.text: These pictures of the Hidden Lake Trailhead were taken just two minutes apart on Friday. One moment hikers were visible on the snowy trail heading to the overlook, and the next moment they were fittingly "hidden" in the clouds.

1013569148377419776.text: While some days you might find beautiful blue skies at Logan Pass, it's not uncommon to find the surrounding peaks clad in thick clouds. Keep in mind that the weather changes quickly in the mountains. Fog may be fleeting or may stick around for hours or even days.

1013569142962544640.text: Even though it's officially summer, it may not feel like it in the park's upper elevations. Logan Pass, the highest point on the Going-to-the-Sun Road, is often cooler, windier, and foggier than other areas in the park.pic.twitter.com/BWm1ap3cCf

1012471838427918336.text:
Monroe married Sinopah (also referred to as Sinopaki), daughter of the Blackfeet chief Lone Walker. Mountains bearing their names are close to Rising Wolf Mountain, creating a family reunion of sorts in the Two Medicine Valley.
#GlacierHistory

1012471837182210048.text: Monroe decided to stay with the Blackfeet and was given the name Rising Wolf. Some say the name refers to his manner of getting out of bed on all fours in the morning.

1012471835986804736.text: The mountain is named after Hugh Monroe, who worked as a Hudson Bay Company agent. Dates for his life are sketchy, but it’s believed he came west around 1817 and was assigned to live with the Blackfeet for a year to learn their language and customs.

1012471832534847488.text: If you’ve been to Two Medicine, it’s hard to miss the hulking red mass that is Rising Wolf Mountain. The popular Dawson-Pitamakan Trail Loop travels almost 20 miles around the circumference of this huge peak.pic.twitter.com/sZxrn6aF7g

1009585519926243328.text: But not all of Glacier’s plants use chlorophyll. Some plants only have a little chlorophyll and others completely lack it. Without the green pigment these unique plants must steal their energy from other plants. For example, the Spotted Coral Root pictured here.pic.twitter.com/7SZ9UnC76o

1009585337457242112.text: Glacier can be a pretty green place! All that green comes from chlorophyll, a green pigment used by most plants to absorb energy from the sun.

1009187139639115776.text: Do you have any tips for kindly reminding people not to litter food items?

1009187134828261376.text:
Food thrown alongside roads draws wildlife nearer to roadways and increases the likelihood they will end up as roadkill. Help us prevent this by remembering that even organic food scraps, like banana and orange peels are still litter. 
#LeaveNoTrace #LNT #GlacierNPSpic.twitter.com/ETndXfafkw

1005425985288671233.text:
In 1910, the park had over 100 glaciers but by 1966 only 35 remained. Today, rising temperatures are shrinking every glacier in the park. In 2015, 26 met the size criteria to be designated active glaciers. 

Learn more: https://www.nps.gov/glac/learn/nature/glaciers.htm … #GlacierWatch

1005425982986043393.text: Do you want to see a specific glacier when you visit the park?

1005425976845656064.text: Sperry Glacier shrank quite a bit since the "Gentleman Explorer" last visited it. By 1966 it was 331 acres and when researchers measured it in 2015 it had shrunk to 198 acres.

1005425972827414528.text: Sperry Glacier was named for Dr. Lyman B. Sperry of Oberlin College, Ohio, the "Gentleman Explorer," who led the first European party to reach the glacier in 1896.pic.twitter.com/0mCTNvGrV9

Th Park had over 100 glaciers when it was established in 1910 but by 1966 there were 35 active glaciers remaining. In 2015, 26 met the size criteria to be designated active glaciers.

Around here people say, “there are 9 months of winter and 3 months of company.” It’s almost true, Glacier had over 3 million visitors last year and most everyone comes in the summer. 

If you’re visiting this summer you’ll be glad you planned ahead: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/index.htm …pic.twitter.com/DgelwCUveC

994974063792656386.text: The first known recommendation that this area become a national park came from Lieutenant John T. Van Orsdale in 1883, when he wrote in the Fort Benton “River Press,” “A great benefit would result to Montana if this section could be set aside as a national park..."

994974060038840321.text: On this day, 108 years ago Glacier National Park was established!  #HappyBirthdayGlacierpic.twitter.com/EwtkudojNf

994719131118325760.text: Bud thought she would get in trouble for leaving the depot during her shift, but when a general superintendent for the Great Northern Railway learned of the incident, it was written up in the company's magazine and Bud was commended for her valiant efforts.

994719130136793094.text: "He died and it was too bad because he wasn’t dead...he wasn’t dead even when those fellows arrived. ‘You go massage him,’ I said, ‘I’m all in,’ and they wouldn’t touch him, and so he died.”

994719128907866112.text: By the time the rescue party arrived two hours later, Bud and a nearby homesteader had built a fire and Bud was feverishly trying to revive the hypothermic man. The rescue party decided the man was already dead, however, and refused to help with the reviving efforts.

994719127876096000.text: In 1924, she received a call on a cold winter night that a boat had capsized on the lake. Bud closed the depot, went home and grabbed her skis and some whiskey. She passed the all-male rescue party that had set out on snowshoes and beat them to the scene.

994719125590233095.text: Norwegian-born Gonhild "Bud" Henderson was a dispatcher at the Great Northern Railway's Belton Depot, just outside the west entrance to Glacier National Park, from 1917-1927. She got the nickname "Bud" because many people had trouble pronouncing "Gonhild."pic.twitter.com/MEOlFivDTP

991712156302311424.text: Over millennia the buttercup plants that were poisonous had a better survival rate than the buttercups that weren’t. Today all buttercups are poisonous to humans and animals.
